awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Rational Design of Alloys with Low-Melting-Point Metals for High-yield, Non-thermal Plasma-assisted Catalytic Production of Ammonia
awd_abstract_narration:
Close to 2% of the world's energy is spent synthesizing ammonia by a chemical process called the Haber-Bosch process.  Plasma catalysis is emerging as a promising alternative method for ammonia synthesis at moderate pressure and temperature, which allows it to rely on renewable energy resources that are more distributed and intermittent in nature. The goal of the proposed collaborative research project is to use computation and experiment to rationally design an alloy catalyst for a new plasma-assisted ammonia synthesis process that requires less energy. The research will also train students from underrepresented and minority groups and support the development and dissemination of educational materials on a general access website.

The project will integrate experiments and simulations in a feedback loop that will culminate with the computational identification of a high-performance low melting point alloy that will be tested in catalytic experiments under an atmospheric plasma.  The fundamental reaction mechanisms under plasma conditions will be elucidated by using kinetic Monte Carlo simulations. The research objectives of the project are: (1) Synthesize gallium alloys and evaluate kinetics of ammonia synthesis in a radio-frequency plasma reactor. (2) Determine recombination kinetics of H and N radicals from "plasma-on-plasma-off" experiments. (3) Calculate energetic descriptors for ammonia synthesis reaction steps under plasma conditions using Density Functional Theory. (4) Develop a kinetic Monte-Carlo model for ammonia formation using graph theoretical approach and cluster expansion. (5) Experimentally test a computationally identified alloy in a plasma reactor.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Haber-Bosch (H-B) process is accountable for producing approximately 1% of global CO₂ emissions due to its high-temperature, high-pressure requirements, driving a critical need to decarbonize ammonia (NH₃) production. Plasma-assisted catalysis offers a promising alternative, yet its development is constrained by a limited mechanistic understanding. Through the development of this research work we aimed to address this knowledge gap using microkinetic models and dielectric-barrier discharge (DBD) plasma reactors, aiming to uncover the mechanisms controlling NH₃ synthesis. Interestingly our group found that nitrogen (N) and hydrogen (H) radicals generated in plasma are essential for catalytic activity, as only their inclusion in models accurately predicts experimental observations. These insights help explain several experimental phenomena, such as comparable activity levels between Fe and Ag (metals with opposite N₂ dissociation abilities), increased NH₃ synthesis on Fe compared to thermal catalysis, and the presence of N₂HY species on catalyst surfaces. Additionally, N radicals are shown to be more significant for nitrophobic metals, while H radicals drive hydrogenation on nitrophilic metals. These findings suggest that further in-situ analyses could refine our understanding of how the plasma environment interacts with catalyst surfaces.

Our group’s findings on experimental details have advanced plasma-driven NH₃ synthesis under practical, ambient conditions. Lastly using non-thermal plasma (NTP) with N₂ and seawater vapor over spherical SiO₂ and M/SiO₂ catalysts demonstrated NH₃ synthesis under low power (2 W) using Co/SiO₂, achieving a synthesis rate of 3.7 mmol g_cat⁻¹ h⁻¹. This approach leverages abundant resources like seawater and renewable energy sources, suggesting a decentralized model for sustainable NH₃ production. Co-relating previous work with our overarching goal to intensify the chemical processes, where we developed a plasma catalytic membrane reactor to optimize NH₃ synthesis rates using a dielectric barrier with CC3 crystals, a porous organic cage, and a molecular-sieve membrane from CC3 material. The unique CC3 cage and membrane structure mitigated plasma-induced NH₃ decomposition, achieving a high synthesis rate of 20.3 μmol min⁻¹ m⁻². Together, these studies highlight the potential of non-thermal plasma catalysis as a sustainable solution to the H-B process, highlighting the importance of mechanistic insights, catalyst design, and reactor configuration to optimize synthesis performance for NH₃ production.

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/13/2024
Modified by: Maria L Carreon
